program_name: MISO Minnesota Demand Response Offerings (LMR, DRR Type I, DRR Type II)
description: MISO offers multiple wholesale demand response product types for Minnesota participants in Zone 1. Load Modifying Resources (LMR) participate in the capacity market through annual Planning Resource Auctions, receiving capacity payments. Demand Response Resources (DRR) participate in energy markets for economic signals. DRR Type I resources cannot follow dispatch instructions and come in blocks with no telemetry requirements, while DRR Type II resources can receive dispatch instructions and provide telemetry. Emergency Demand Response (EDR) is being eliminated in Planning Year 2025/26. MISO is implementing significant reforms with new LMR Type I (6-hour notification) and LMR Type II (30-minute notification) categories effective 2028/29 planning year.

service_territories: MISO Zone 1 (Minnesota, Wisconsin, North Dakota, South Dakota)

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Minimum 100 kW for LMR. Minimum 1 MW for energy market participation. Behind-the-meter generation (BTMG) resources >=10 MW must provide generator availability data to MISO.

resource_types: battery energy storage (as LMR, not as ESR which has different rules)

penalty_structure.penalty_description: Previously, penalty for non-performing LMRs was 3x LMP times MW shortfall. MISO is proposing new penalty structure of VOLL times MW shortfall. For DRR Type I spinning reserve, over 40% of resources did not perform adequately in 2023-24 with only small penalties applied. Performance requirements: DR must demonstrate at least 50% of registered capability via MISO Event or real power test. DRR Type II resources limited to offering only the performance level achieved in most recent deployment or test until retested.

nomination_bidding.nomination_deadline: Prior to Planning Resource Auction for planning year
nomination_bidding.bidding_structure: DRR resources submit energy offers into Day-Ahead and/or Real-Time Markets. DRRs that clear MISO PRA are required to offer into Day-Ahead Energy Market. MISO is proposing to prohibit DRRs from submitting offers below the Net Benefits Price Threshold (NBPT), which has ranged from $28 to $52/MWh. DRRs can only clear up to 40% of spinning reserve requirement. EDR resources submit EDR Offers with price cap historically at VOLL ($3,500/MWh, increasing to $10,000/MWh effective Sept 30, 2025).

special_attributes: LMR can be Demand Response or Behind-the-Meter Generation (BTMG)
LMRs aggregated up to Load Zone CPNode level only
DRR Type I: cannot follow dispatch instructions, no telemetry, block-based, cannot provide regulating reserves or ramp products
DRR Type II: can follow dispatch instructions, requires telemetry, can provide regulating reserves, spinning reserves, supplemental resources, and ramp products
Non-BTMG DRR must provide hourly meter data for all hours every 45 days, updated bi-weekly
Settlement data accessible via Market Portal within 7 days of Operating Day
DR only paid if Locational Marginal Price > Net Benefits Price Threshold (NBPT)
Winter season requirement: notification time â‰¤6 hours, must be interruptible for at least first 5 times requested
EDR program being eliminated in Planning Year 2025/26
LMR reforms proposed: LMR Type I (6-hour notification, deployed during EEA warnings) and LMR Type II (30-minute notification, deployed during emergency events) effective 2028/29
Minnesota-specific: Zone 1 clearing prices, cold climate considerations with winter peak importance

program_evolution.change_description: MISO established initial demand response framework with VOLL set at $3,500/MWh
DR resources began receiving capacity payments through Planning Resource Auctions
Zone 1 capacity prices spiked to $237/MW-day (annual auction before seasonal structure)
First seasonal Planning Resource Auction implemented. Zone 1 prices dropped to $2-15/MW-day range across seasons due to capacity surplus

MISO proposed significant DRR reforms including prohibition of offers below NBPT, enhanced meter data requirements, and modified reference level calculations. Zone 1 seasonal prices: Summer $30, Fall $15, Winter $0.75, Spring $34.10 per MW-day. Independent Market Monitor raised concerns about DR performance (40% DRR Type I failure rate) and $800M in capacity payments since 2019.

VOLL increased from $3,500 to $10,000/MWh (effective Sept 30). EDR program elimination fast-tracked to Planning Year 2025/26. Minnesota PUC approved Xcel Energy's 600 MW battery storage plan by 2030 and 200 MW distributed battery network (Capacity*Connect). Debate over demand response aggregator rules.
LMR reforms effective Planning Year 2028/29: new LMR Type I (6-hour notification) and Type II (30-minute notification) categories, 100% capacity credit for <30-minute LMRs

integration_metadata.notes:
BATTERY SUITABILITY ASSESSMENT:

1. LMR Program - HIGHLY SUITABLE for batteries:
   - Behind-the-meter battery systems can participate as LMR
   - Minimum 100 kW capacity (easily met by commercial batteries)
   - Receive capacity payments: Zone 1 cleared at $30/MW-day (Summer 2024), $34.10/MW-day (Spring 2025), $15/MW-day (Fall 2024), $0.75/MW-day (Winter 2024-25)
   - 6-hour notification time standard (ample time for battery scheduling)
   - Must demonstrate 50% of registered capability via test or MISO Event
   - Upcoming reforms: LMR Type II with 30-minute notification will receive 100% capacity credit (2028/29)
   - Battery SOC management compatible with 6-hour advance notice

2. DRR Type II Program - MODERATELY SUITABLE for batteries:
   - Can follow dispatch instructions (excellent for battery control systems)
   - Requires telemetry (standard for modern battery systems)
   - Can provide multiple services: regulating reserves, spinning reserves, supplemental resources, ramp products
   - Participate in Day-Ahead and Real-Time Energy Markets
   - Must offer above Net Benefits Price Threshold ($28-52/MWh)
   - Limited to 40% of spinning reserve requirement
   - Performance-based offering limits: can only offer at level of most recent deployment/test
   - Meter data requirements: hourly data for all hours, updated bi-weekly
   - Payment when LMP > NBPT

3. DRR Type I Program - LIMITED SUITABILITY for batteries:
   - Cannot follow dispatch instructions (less optimal for battery flexibility)
   - No telemetry requirements (wastes battery monitoring capabilities)
   - Block-based operation (not ideal for battery granular control)
   - Cannot provide regulating reserves or ramp products (misses key battery strengths)
   - Can only provide offline Short-Term Reserve
   - Performance issues documented: 40%+ failure rate in 2023-24

4. EDR Program - NOT APPLICABLE:
   - Being eliminated in Planning Year 2025/26
   - Was only called once in MISO history
   - Not worth pursuing for new battery projects

MINNESOTA-SPECIFIC ADVANTAGES:
- Zone 1 has reasonable capacity prices (avoided Missouri Zone 5 spike to $719.81/MW-day)
- Cold climate creates winter peak demand (unique opportunity vs summer-only programs)
- Winter season requirement: â‰¤6 hour notification, minimum 5 interruptions
- Minneapolis-St. Paul metro provides large commercial/industrial load centers
- Xcel Energy deploying 200 MW distributed battery network (Capacity*Connect) - shows utility support
- Minnesota PUC approved 600 MW battery storage by 2030 in Xcel IRP
- State incentives for solar-plus-storage and energy equity programs
- First standalone BESS project (Snowshoe) approved by Minnesota PUC in 2024

KEY RISKS:
- MISO proposing strict performance requirements and reference level calculations (2024 reforms)
- DRR cannot offer below NBPT ($28-52/MWh) - may limit arbitrage opportunities
- Penalty structure changing to VOLL Ã— MW shortfall (increasing from $3,500 to $10,000/MWh in 2025)
- Independent Market Monitor scrutiny after $800M in capacity payments and performance concerns
- Low aggregator participation in MISO vs other ISOs
- Minnesota considering new rules on demand response aggregators (Aug 2024 PUC debate)

RECOMMENDATION:
Battery systems in Minnesota should pursue LMR registration for capacity payments (straightforward, well-compensated) and evaluate DRR Type II for energy market participation if system has sophisticated dispatch controls and telemetry. The combination of capacity payments ($30/MW-day summer) plus energy market participation provides diversified revenue streams. Avoid DRR Type I due to operational constraints that don't leverage battery capabilities. Monitor upcoming LMR Type II reforms (30-minute notification, 100% credit) for enhanced opportunities starting 2028/29. Minnesota's winter peak and utility support for battery deployment make this a strong market for battery participation.

DATA QUALITY NOTES:
- Comprehensive public documentation available from MISO
- Recent auction results provide concrete pricing data
- Business Practice Manuals (BPM-026, BPM-011) define technical requirements
- Active stakeholder process with regular workshop presentations
- Performance data available through Independent Market Monitor reports
- Zone 1 specific clearing prices documented for 2022-2025 planning years
- Some program details in PDF format not fully accessible (images/formatting)
- Ongoing regulatory changes require monitoring (2024-2028 reform timeline)
- Minnesota PUC activities show state-level support and evolution of programs
